    Nuevo Leon, 66265, Mexico</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">Attention:
    Investor Relations Department</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">Telephone
    number: (52-81) 8863-12-00</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">You
    may obtain additional information about Vitro through its web site al <font color="#0000FF">www.vitro.com</font></font></p>

    information contained therein is not part of this annual report.</font></p>
  <p>&nbsp;</p>
  <b><hr NOSHADE>
  </b>
  <p class=2ndheading style='
punctuation-wrap:hanging;text-autospace:ideograph-numeric ideograph-other;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A NAME="item11"><font size="3"><b>Item
    11. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.</b></font>
    </A></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">Our
    business activities require that we hold or issue financial instruments, principally
    debt obligations in pesos or in U.S. dollars, that expose us to market risk
    caused by movements in interest rates or currency exchange rates. To hedge
    these risks, we utilize derivative instruments. All financial instruments
    held by us are for purposes other than trading.</font></p>
  <p class=SideHeadItalic style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>Interest
    Rate Risk</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">Our
    exposure to market risk associated with changes in interest rates relates
    primarily to our debt obligations, most of which bear interest at floating
    rates. We periodically enter into interest rate swap agreements to hedge future
    interest payments under floating rate debt. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">The
    table below provides information as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 regarding our
    debt obligations that are sensitive to changes in interest rates. For these
    debt obligations, the table presents principal cash flows and related weighted
    average interest rates by expected maturity dates. The fair value of long-term
    debt is based on the quoted market prices for the same or similar issues,
    as well as on the present value of future cash flows. The rates used to discount
    the future cash flows of debt instruments are LIBOR and the Mexican <i>Certificados
    de la Tesoreria de la Federacion</i> (&quot;CETES&quot;) rates that match the remaining
    life of the instrument. In the case of interest rate swaps, the table presents
    notional amounts and weighted average interest rates by contractual maturity
    dates. Notional amounts are used to calculate the contractual payments to
    be exchanged under each contract.</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=858 align="center">
    <tr>

    subsidiaries.</font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="1" color="#000000"><br>
    (2)&nbsp;&nbsp; Floating interest rates are based on market rates as of December&nbsp;31,
    2001 plus the weighted average spread for Vitro and its subsidiaries.</font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="1" color="#000000"><br>
    (3)&nbsp;&nbsp; Market rates for U.S. dollar-denominated debt are based on
    the LIBOR curve.</font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="1" color="#000000"><br>
    (4)&nbsp;&nbsp; Market rates for Peso-denominated debt are based on the CETES
    and TIIE and assume a flat yield curve (there is no long-term yield curve
    in Mexican pesos).</font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="1" color="#000000"><br>
    (5)&nbsp;&nbsp; Based on the pesos-per-UDI value published by Banco de Mexico
    in the Official Gazette of the Federation, which in turn, is based on the
    INPC.</font></p>

  <p class=SideHeading style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>Exchange
    Rate Risk</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">We
    periodically enter into currency swap agreements to mitigate our exposure
    to inflation in Mexico. The table below provides information as of December&nbsp;31,
    2001 regarding our debt obligations that are sensitive to inflation in Mexico.
    We utilize currency exchange swaps to exchange UDI-denominated debt for U.S.
    dollar-denominated debt.</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="1" color="#000000">(1)In
    millions of UDIs represented by notes issued by Vitro in the Mexican Stock
    Exchange.<br>
    (2)In millions of U.S. dollars.</font></p>
  <p class=SideHeadItalic style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>Natural
    Gas Price Risk</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">Natural
    gas is the principal fuel consumed by our glass furnaces. We intend to enter
    into natural gas purchase contracts for hedging purposes only, and we will
    designate them as cash flow hedges to cover our anticipated natural gas requirements.
    Accordingly, these natural gas hedges will be purchases in the ordinary course
    of business, and thus, not subject to derivative accounting.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">As
    of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we maintained hedges on the price of natural gas
    for approximately 50% of our consumption needs with Petroleos Mexicanos, which
    we refer to as &quot;Pemex,&quot; at a price of $4.00&nbsp;per Million British Thermal
    Unit, which we refer to as &quot;MMBTU.&quot; These hedges are take-or-pay agreements
    by which we must purchase approximately 50% of our natural gas consumption
    needs from Pemex at a price that may be higher than the current market price
    of natural gas at the time of purchase. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, the
    market price per MMBTU was $2.10.</font></p>
  <p class=CSMNormal style='text-align:
justify;'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>Anchor
    Glass</i></font></p>
  <p class=CSMNormal style='text-align:
justify;'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>Certain
    Tax Benefits</i></font></p>
  <p class=CSMNormal style='text-align:
justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">In
    1989, we acquired Anchor Glass, which at the time was the second-largest manufacturer
    of glass containers in the United States. Anchor Glass filed for protection
    under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in September 1996.
    In February 1997, Anchor Glass sold substantially all of its assets to an
    affiliate of Consumers Packaging Inc., which we refer to as &quot;New Anchor&quot;,
    and Owens-Brockway Glass Container, Inc. The proceeds of the sale of Anchor
    Glass were used in their entirety to pay expenses of the bankruptcy estate
    and to repay creditors of Anchor Glass. As a result of the disposal in 1997
    of Anchor Glass, the tax benefits resulting from utilization of net operating
    losses of Anchor generated in 1996 are included in the 1997, 1998 and 1999
    statement of operations as &quot;Income on disposal of discontinued operations.&quot;</font></p>
  <p class=CSMNormal><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000"><i>PBGC
    Limited Guaranty</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">In
    connection with the sale of assets of Anchor Glass to New Anchor, we executed
    a term sheet which contemplated that we would enter into an agreement pursuant
    to which we would guarantee on a limited basis the payment to the Pension
    Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&quot;the PBGC&quot;), an independent federal agency that
    guarantees certain pension obligations, of all or a portion of any unfunded
    benefit liabilities of three defined benefit plans which subsequently were
    merged into the Anchor Glass Container Pension Plan (the &quot;AGCPP&quot;). We would
    be liable under such limited guaranty only if the AGCPP terminates (in other
    than a successful standard termination) prior to August&nbsp;1, 2006 and the
    PBGC is unable to recover the full amount of such liabilities from New Anchor
    or any members of its controlled group. The maximum amount of our limited
    guaranty and the dates on which payments under the limited guaranty could
    be required (based on the termination date of the AGCPP) are set forth below.
    In addition, as part of our arrangement with the PBGC, tax liens in favor
    of the AGCPP were filed in an original amount of approximately $23&nbsp;million
    on all of the domestic assets of Vitro Packaging Corporation, and such liens
    currently remain valid.</font></p>

        1, 2011</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$56
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2003-July 31, 2003</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">14</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2004</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2010</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$49
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2003-January 31, 2003</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">12</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2004</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2010</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$42
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2004-July 31, 2004</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">10</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2005</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2009</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$35
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2004-January 31, 2005</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">8</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2005</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2009</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$28
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2005-July 31, 2005</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">6</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2006</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2008</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$21
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2005-January 31, 2006</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">4</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2006</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2008</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$14
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width=249 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2006-July 31, 2006</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=138 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
        1, 2007</font></td>
      <td width=147 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">August
        1, 2007</font></td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$7
        Million</font></td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">However,
    according to New Anchor's Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended
    December&nbsp;31, 2001 (the &quot;NA 10-K&quot;), New Anchor, effective December&nbsp;31,
    2001, along with Glenshaw Glass Company, Inc. (&quot;GGC&quot;), created the Glass Companies
    Multiemployer Pension Plan (the &quot;MEPP&quot;) from the merger of the AGCPP and GGC's
    defined benefit plan for hourly employees. In the NA 10-K, New Anchor expressed
    its belief, based on an opinion of its counsel, that the MEPP satisfies the
    definition of a multiemployer plan for purposes of the Employee Retirement
    Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (&quot;ERISA&quot;) and the Internal Revenue
    Code of 1986, as amended (the &quot;Code&quot;). For accounting purposes, the MEPP does
    not constitute a multiemployer plan, because New Anchor and GGC are related
    entities. For purposes of ERISA and the Code, more than one employer must
    be required to contribute to a plan for it to constitute a multiemployer plan.
    If New Anchor and GGC are deemed to be a single employer, then such requirement
    may not be satisfied. New Anchor also disclosed in the NA 10-K that if the
    AGCPP remained a single employer plan, it would have been required to contribute
    approximately $140&nbsp;million to the AGCPP through 2004.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">On
    April&nbsp;15, 2002, New Anchor filed a pre-negotiated plan of reorganization
    under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. On June&nbsp;6, 2002, the
    PBGC filed with the bankruptcy court a notice of objection (the &quot;Notice
    of Objection&quot;) to the disclosure statement filed by New Anchor in connection
    with such plan of reorganization (the &quot;Disclosure Statement&quot;). The
    PBGC objected to the Disclosure Statement on the grounds that New Anchor failed
    to inform its creditors of the potential consequences of a determination by
    the DOL that the MEPP does not meet the requirements of a multiemployer pension
    plan under ERISA. In the Notice of Objection, the PBGC stated that at its
    request, the DOL is currently reviewing the purported merger of the AGCPP
    with the GGC defined benefit plan to determine whether the applicable statutory
    and regulatory requirements have been satisfied. In addition, the PBGC has
    filed contingent claims with the bankruptcy court in the amount of approximately
    $218 million, which represents the amount by which the AGCPP would have been
    underfunded on a plan termination basis as of February 28, 2002 if it remained
    a single employer plan. If the MEPP is determined to be a multiemployer plan
    then our risk of incurring material liability in connection with PBGC limited
    guaranty will be reduced. However, our risk of incurring material liability
    in connection with the PBGC limited guaranty depends on positions to be taken
    by the IRS, DOL, PBGC and potentially, the courts. Accordingly, no assurances
    can be given.</font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;
  <hr NOSHADE>
  <p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item12">Item
    12. Description of Securities Other than Equity Securities.</A></b></font></p>
  <p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Not applicable.</font></p>
  <b>
  <hr NOSHADE>
  </b>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:center'><font size="4" color="#000000" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>PART
    II</b></font>
  <p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item13"><font size="3">Item
    13. Defaults, Dividend Arrearages and Delinquencies</font>.</A></b></font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify'><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000000">In
    September 1996, Anchor Glass filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the
    United States Bankruptcy Code. In connection with the bankruptcy proceedings,
    Anchor Glass stopped payments of principal and interests due on approximately
    $470 million in aggregate principal amount of its various series of outstanding
    debt securities (of which, $170 million, $100 million and $200 million ranked
    senior secured, senior unsecured and senior subordinated debt securities,
    respectively). In February 1997, Anchor Glass sold substantially all of its
    assets to an affiliate of Consumers Packaging Inc., and to Owens-Brockway
    Glass Container, Inc., and in connection with such sale, the creditors committee
    of Anchor Glass issued to Vitro a liabilities release. </font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify'><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A NAME="item14"><b>Item
    14. Material Modifications to the Rights of Security Holders and Use of Proceeds.</b></A></font></p>
  <p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Not applicable.</font></p>
  <p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item15">Item
    15. [Reserved]</A></b></font></p>
  <p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item16">Item
    16. [Reserved]</A></b></font></p>
  <hr NOSHADE>
  <p class=2ndheading align=center style='text-align:center;punctuation-wrap:hanging;text-autospace:ideograph-numeric ideograph-other;'><font size="4" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>PART
    III</b></font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify'><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item17">Item
    17. Financial Statements.</A></b></font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify;
punctuation-wrap:hanging;text-autospace:ideograph-numeric ideograph-other;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    Vitro is furnishing financial statements pursuant to the instructions of Item
    18 of Form 20-F.&nbsp;</font></p>
  <p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><A NAME="item18">Item
    18. Financial Statements.</A></b></font></p>
  <p class=Style0 style='text-align:justify'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    consolidated financial statements of Vitro, S.A. de C.V. attached to this
    annual report on Form 20-F have been audited by Deloitte &amp; Touche, independent
    public accountants, as in their reports with respect to the consolidated financial
    statements.</font>

    19. Exhibits. </A> </b></font>

<body lang=ES class="Normal" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<div class=Section1>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>Independent
    Auditors' Report</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Board
    of Directors and Stockholders of <br>Vitro, S.A. de C.V. </font><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>San
    Pedro Garza Garcia, N. L.</font></p>
  <p align=right style='text-align:right;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">(Amounts
    in millions of Mexican pesos) </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">We
    have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Vitro, S.A. de
    C.V. and Subsidiaries (the &quot;Company&quot;) as of December 31, 2000 and
    2001, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders'
    equity and changes in financial position for each of the three years in the
    period ended December 31, 2001 (all expressed in millions of Constant Mexican
    pesos as of December 31, 2001) . These financial statements are the responsibility
    of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on
    these financial statements based on our audits. The financial statements of
    the subsidiaries and associated companies named in note 2 b) , were audited
    by other auditors and our opinion, regarding the amounts reported by these
    companies, is based only on the reports of such other auditors. The total
    assets of the companies above mentioned represent 21% in 2000 and 2001 of
    the consolidated total assets, whereas their net sales represent 28% of the
    consolidated net sales in 1999, 26% in 2000 and 28% in 2001.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">We
    conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted
    in the United States of America. Those standards require that we plan and
    perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial
    statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining,
    on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial
    statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used
    and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall
    financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable
    basis for our opinion.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In
    our opinion, based upon our audits and the reports of other auditors mentioned
    in the first paragraph, such consolidated financial statements present fairly,
    in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Vitro, S.A.
    de C.V. and Subsidiaries as of December 31, 2000 and 2001, and the consolidated
    results of their operations, changes in their stockholders' equity and changes
    in their financial position for the years ended December 31, 1999, 2000 and
    2001, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in Mexico.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Effective
    January 1, 2000 the Company applied the provisions of the new Bulletin D-4,
    &quot;Accounting Treatment of Income Tax, Tax on Assets and Workers' Profit Sharing&quot;.
    The effects in net income for the years ended December 31, 2000 and 2001 were
    increases of Ps. 112 and Ps. 66, respectively. Additionally, the effect in
    comprehensive loss for the year 2000 was an increase of Ps. 2,468 (see note
    3 o) .</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Accounting
    principles generally accepted in Mexico vary in certain significant respects
    from accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
    The application of the latter would have affected the determination of net
    income for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2001 and
    the determination of stockholders' equity at December 31,1999, 2000 and 2001
    to the extent summarized in note 22.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Our
    audits also comprehended the translation of Mexican peso amounts into United
    States dollar amounts and, in our opinion, such translation has been made
    in conformity with the basis stated in note </font><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2
    a) . Such United States dollar amounts are presented solely for the convenience
    of readers.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    accompanying financial statements have been translated into English language
    for the convenience of readers.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">February
    14, 2002<br>
    April 15, 2002, as to note 21a)<br>
    Junio 3, 2002, as to note 21b)<br></font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Junio
    19, 2002, as to note 21c) and 22</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><img src="flex.jpg" width="599" height="784" align="middle"><br clear=all>
    </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><img src="com.jpg" width="600" height="1283"></p>

  <p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
    Vitro, S.A. de C.V. and Subsidiaries</font><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
    Consolidated Statements of Stockholder's Equity</font><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>

    per share amounts)</i></font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=960 align="center">
    <tr>
      <td width=175 valign=top class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=82 nowrap rowspan=4 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Capital
          stock</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td width=87 nowrap rowspan=4 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Treasury
          Stock and paid-in capital</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td width=107 nowrap rowspan=4 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Shortfall
          in restatement of capital</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td width=88 nowrap rowspan=4 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Cumulative
          effect of deferred taxes</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td width=83 nowrap rowspan=4 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Minimum
          pension liability adjustment</font></b></div>
      </td>

        <div align="right"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">(152)</font></div>
      </td>

          5,867</font></div>
      </td>

  <br>
  <hr NOSHADE>
  <font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
  Vitro, S.A. de C.V. and Subsidiaries</font><font size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
  Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</font><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
  <i>(Millions of constant Mexican pesos as of December 31, 2001, except for per
  share amounts)</i></font>
<p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>1.
    Activities of the company</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Vitro,
    S.A. de C.V. (&quot;Vitro&quot;) is a holding company, the subsidiaries of which manufacture
    and market glass and plastic containers, thermoformed articles, aluminum cans,
    flat glass for architectural and automotive uses, glassware for table and
    kitchen use, fiberglass insulation and reinforcements, certain chemical products
    and minerals, household appliances and capital goods.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>2.
    Basis of presentation and principles of consolidation</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a) Basis of presentation</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    consolidated financial statements of Vitro and its subsidiaries (the &quot;Company&quot;) are prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in
    Mexico (&quot;Mexican GAAP&quot;) , as further described in note 3.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    consolidated financial statements presented herein are expressed in millions
    of constant Mexican pesos as of December 31, 2001, except per share amounts.
    However, solely for the convenience of users, the consolidated financial statements
    as of and for the year ended December 31, 2001 have been translated into United
    States (US) dollars at the rate of 9.1695 pesos per one dollar, the rate of
    exchange determined by Banco de Mexico (Mexico's Central Bank) on December
    31, 2001.  The translation should not be construed as a representation that
    the peso amounts shown could be converted into US dollars at such rate or
    at any rate.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">All
    references to dollars, in the financial statements and these notes, correspond
    to dollars of the United States of America </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    Consolidated subsidiaries</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    Those companies in which Vitro holds, directly or indirectly, more than 50%
    of the capital stock or which Vitro controls are included in the consolidated
    financial statements.  For those companies in which Vitro has joint control,
    the proportionate consolidation method is used.  All significant intercompany
    balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    Vitro's subsidiaries Vitromatic, S. A. de C. V. and subsidiaries; Empresas
    Comegua, S.A. and subsidiaries; and Vitro Flex, S. A. de C. V.; as well as
    certain other subsidiaries and associated companies which in the aggregate
    are not material, are audited by firms of public accountants other than the
    Company's principal auditor.  </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In
    order to consolidate the financial statements of subsidiaries located in the
    United States of America, the effects of inflation were taken into consideration
    in accordance with Bulletin B-10, as amended, which is the principal difference
    between US generally accepted accounting principles (&quot;US GAAP&quot;) and Mexican
    GAAP for these companies.  Such companies' financial statements are initially
    prepared in accordance with US GAAP and are translated into Mexican pesos
    under the current rate method.  The assets, liabilities, stockholders' equity
    (except capital stock) and the income statement accounts are translated into
    Mexican pesos using the exchange rate as of the date of the most recent balance
    sheet presented.  The cumulative translation adjustment is included as a component
    of stockholders' equity.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c)
    Investment in associated companies</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"> Associated companies are those companies in which Vitro holds,
    as a permanent investment, less than 50% of the capital stock and maintains
    significant influence.  Such investments are accounted for by the equity method.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>
    3. Principal accounting policies</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a)  Accounting
    method for the treatment of the effects of inflation</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    The consolidated financial statements of the Company have been prepared in
    accordance with Bulletin B-10, &quot;Recognition of the Effects of Inflation in
    Financial Information&quot;, as amended, issued by the Mexican Institute of Public
    Accountants (&quot;IMCP&quot;) , which relates to the recognition of the effects of inflation.
    The Third Amendment to Bulletin B-10 (the &quot;Third Amendment&quot;) has been adopted
    in preparing such consolidated financial statements.  The Third Amendment
    requires the restatement of all comparative financial statements to constant
    pesos as of the date of the most recent balance sheet presented.  For that
    purpose, Vitro's Mexican subsidiaries and associated companies use the &quot;Indice
    Nacional de Precios al Consumidor&quot; (Mexican National Consumer Price Index:
    &quot;INPC&quot;) , published by Banco de Mexico; Vitro's US subsidiaries use the Consumer
    Price Index - All Urban Consumers - All Items, Unadjusted (&quot;CPI&quot;) published
    by the US Labor Department, and are translated using the exchange rate at
    the end of the last period presented.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"> Bulletin B-12 set the rules related to the statement of changes
    in financial position.  This statement presents the sources and uses of funds
    during the period measured as the differences, in constant pesos, between
    the beginning and ending balances of balance sheet items adjusted by the excess
    (shortfall) in restatement of capital.  As required by Bulletin B-12, the
    monetary effect and the effect of changes in exchange rates are not considered
    non-cash items in the determination of resources generated from operations
    due to the fact they affect the purchasing power of the entity.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    Cash and cash equivalents</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    Highly liquid short-term investments with original maturity of ninety days
    or less, consisting primarily of Mexican Government Treasury Bonds and money
    market instruments, are classified as cash equivalents. They are valued at
    the lower of acquisition cost plus accrued yields or estimated net realizable
    value. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c) Financial instruments</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Assets
    and liabilities resulting from any financial instrument, except for such instruments
    held to maturity, are recorded in the balance sheet at fair value. The financial
    instruments held to maturity are valued at their acquisition cost.  The effects
    of valuation of the financial instruments, including their cost and yield
    are recorded in the corresponding year in the statement of operations.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Financial
    instruments for hedging purposes, are valued using the same criteria of valuation
    of the assets or liabilities hedged, and the effect of such valuation is recognized
    in net income, net of costs, expenses, or income from the assets or liabilities
    whose risks are being hedged.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>d)
    Inventories and cost of sales</i> </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Inventories
    are valued at the price of the last purchase made during the year or at the
    latest production cost without exceeding the net realizable value.  Cost of
    sales is determined by using the price of the last purchase prior to the date
    of consumption or the latest production cost at the time of sale.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>e) Land, buildings,
    machinery and equipment</i> </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Expenditures
    for land, buildings, machinery and equipment, including renewals and improvements
    that extend useful lives, are capitalized.  The Company follows the principles
    of the Fifth Amendment to Bulletin B-10, under which, fixed assets are restated
    under the method of consumer price index adjustment, using the INPC.  The
    initial balance to apply the INPC was the net replacement value as of December
    31, 1996. For machinery and equipment purchased in a foreign country, the
    restatement is based on a general consumer price index from the country of
    origin and the exchange rate at the end of each period. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Maintenance
    and repair expenses are recorded as costs and expenses in the period when
    they are incurred.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Depreciation
    is calculated using the straight-line method, taking into consideration the
    estimated useful life of the asset, in order to depreciate the original cost
    and the revaluation.  The depreciation begins in the month in which the asset
    is placed in service.  The estimated useful lives of the assets are as follows:</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=368 align="center">
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=288 nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=80 nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <b><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Years</font></b></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Buildings</font></td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">20
        to 50</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Machinery
        and equipment</font></td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">5
        to 30</font></td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>f)
    Excess of cost over fair value of net assets acquired</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    The excess of cost over fair value of net assets acquired is amortized on
    a straight-line basis over a period of 20 years.  Amortization expense for
    the years ended December 31, 1999, 2000 and 2001 was Ps. 12 , Ps. 15  and
    Ps. 28 , respectively. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>g)  Excess of
    book value over cost of net assets acquired</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    excess of book value over cost of net assets acquired is amortized over the
    period that the subsidiary or associated company is expected to be integrated
    into the operations of the group, which cannot exceed 5 years. Amortization
    for the year ended December 31, 2000 was Ps. 57.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>h)
    Seniority premiums, retirement plans and severance payments</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"> Seniority premiums and pension plans for all personnel are considered
    as costs in the periods in which services are rendered.  Periodic costs are
    calculated in accordance with Bulletin D-3 issued by the IMCP, and the actuarial
    computations were made by an independent actuary, using estimates of the salaries
    that will be in effect at the time of payment. The past service cost is amortized
    over the average period required for workers to reach their retirement age.
    The method used is the projected unit credit. Effective year 2000 the Company
    is funding a trust in order to cover the payment of such liabilities.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"> Severance payments are expensed in the period in which such
    payments are made.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>i) Excess (shortfall)
    in restatement of capital</i> </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">This
    item, which is an element of stockholders' equity, reflects the accumulated
    effect of holding non-monetary assets and the effect of the initial monetary
    position gain or loss.  The accumulated effect of holding non-monetary assets
    represents the difference between the specific values of non-monetary assets
    in excess of or below the increase attributable to general inflation as measured
    by the INPC and CPI.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i> j)
    Restatement of capital stock and retained earnings</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Capital
    stock and retained earnings, for Mexican subsidiaries, are restated using
    the INPC from the respective dates such capital was contributed or net income
    generated to the date of the most recent balance sheet presented.  Retained
    earnings for US subsidiaries are restated using the CPI.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>k) Employee stock option plan</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    An employee stock option plan (see note 13b) was adopted in 1998.  The Company
    is accounting for stock-based compensation using a fair value based method.
    Compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the value of the
    stock option award and is recognized over the vesting period.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>l) Transactions
    in foreign currency for Mexican subsidiaries </i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">All
    transactions in foreign currency are translated at the exchange rate as of
    the date of such transactions.  In accordance with the Third Amendment, such
    transactions are restated using the INPC.  Monetary assets and liabilities
    denominated in foreign currency are translated into Mexican pesos at the exchange
    rate at the date of the financial statements.  Exchange fluctuations are recorded
    in the statements of operations as part of the total financing cost.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>m) Revenue recognition
    </i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Revenues and related
    costs are recognized in the period in which risks and benefits are transferred
    to purchasers, which generally coincides with the shipment of products to
    costumers in satisfaction of orders.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>n) Gain (loss)
    from monetary position</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The gain (loss) from
    monetary position reflects the result of holding monetary assets and liabilities
    during periods of inflation.  Values stated in current monetary units decrease
    in purchasing power over time.  This means that losses are incurred by holding
    monetary assets over time, whereas gains are realized by maintaining monetary
    liabilities.  The net effect is presented in the statements of operations
    as part of the total financing cost.  For subsidiaries located in the US the
    result from monetary position is calculated using the CPI.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>o)
    Income tax, tax on assets and profit sharing to workers</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Effective
    January 1, 2000, the Company applies the provisions of the new Bulletin D-4
    &quot;Accounting Treatment of Income Tax, Tax on Assets and Workers' Profit Sharing&quot;,
    issued by the IMCP.  As required by this bulletin, deferred income taxes are
    provided for differences between the book and tax value of assets and liabilities
    and deferred workers' profit sharing for temporary differences between the
    financial and adjusted tax income, that are expected to reverse in the future.
    Additionally, the tax on assets paid is recognized as an asset. Until 1999,
    deferred taxes were provided only for identifiable, non-recurring timing differences
    that were expected to reverse over a definite period of time, and the tax
    on assets paid was recognized in the statement of operations. The effects
    in net income on the years ended December 31, 2000 and 2001 were increases
    of Ps. 112 and Ps. 66, respectively. Additionally, the effect in comprehensive
    loss for the year 2000 was an increase of Ps. 2,468 (note 13 j) .</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>p)
    Earnings per share</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Earnings
    per share are computed by dividing income by the weighted average number of
    shares outstanding during each period.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>q)
      Use of estimates</i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">
    The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted
    accounting principles, requires management to make estimates and assumptions
    that affect the reported amounts in these consolidated financial statements
    and in the related disclosures.  Actual results could differ from those estimated.<i>
    </i>                                 </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>4. Discontinued
    operations</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>Anchor
    Glass Container Corporation (&quot;Anchor&quot;) </i></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As
    a result of the disposal in 1996 of Anchor, a wholly owned subsidiary of Vitro,
    the 1999 tax benefit of Ps. 573, resulting from utilization of net operating
    losses of Anchor generated in 1996, are presented in the 1999 statement of
    operations as &quot;Income on disposal of discontinued operations&quot;.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As
    part of Anchor's disposal in a transaction approved by the Bankruptcy Court,
    Vitro provided to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&quot;PBGC&quot;) ,
    a United States governmental agency that guarantees pensions, a limited guarantee
    of Anchor's under funded pension  liability.  No payments would be made under
    the guarantee unless the PBGC terminates any of Anchor's pension plans, and
    the guarantee would be payable only to the extent the PBGC could not otherwise
    recover the under funded liabilities from the entity that purchased Anchor's
    assets.  The amount of the guarantee is limited to $ 70 million.  Payments
    would not begin until August 1, 2002, and would then generally be payable
    in equal semiannual installments over the following 10 years.  Payments would
    not bear interest.  The amount and the term of the guarantee would be proportionately
    reduced if the pension plans were terminated after January 31, 2002.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Beginning
    February, 2002, this guarantee was reduced to $ 63 million, and would be reduced
    semiannually by $ 7 million until August 1, 2006 when this guarantee expires.</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>8.

    in foreign currency (all of which are denominated in US dollars) totaled Ps.
    2,954 and Ps. 3,254, respectively.</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Certain
    of the Company's long-term debt agreements contain restrictions and covenants
    that require the maintenance of various financial ratios.  The Company has
    complied with the restrictions and covenants during 2001.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Debt
    of the Company totaling Ps. 1,050 is collateralized with fixed assets and
    trade accounts receivable with a book value of Ps. 3,827  as of December 31,
    2001.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">During 2001 the Company
    entered into several interest rate swaps. The contracts resulted in swapping
    variable interest rates for fixed interest rates on certain debt agreements
    with total principal of Ps. 7,134. The weighted average fixed interest rate
    was 5.74%. The amount charged in the income statement in 2001 was Ps. 30.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Additionally, during
    2001 the Company entered into several foreign currency forward contracts to
    convert UDIS denominated debt totalling 515 million UDIS (Ps. 1,434) to dollars.
    The favorable effect in net income was Ps. 154.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>10.
    Pension plans and seniority premiums</b></font></p>

  <p style='line-height:
15.0pt;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>11. Commitments
    and contingencies</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a)
    </i>In October, 2000, several subsidiaries of Vitro, S.A. de C.V. which have
    facilities throughout Monterrey, Mexico and the Mexico City area, entered
    into a 15 year energy purchase agreement for approximately 110 MW (&quot;Megawatts&quot;)
    of electricity with Enron Energia Industrial de Mexico, S. de R.L. de C.V.
    (&quot;Enron Mexico&quot;) , a subsidiary of Enron Industrial Energy of Mexico Holding
    I, LLC, (&quot;Enron&quot;) .  The purchase price of electricity is variable.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">On
    October 19, 2001, Enron sold 80% of its common shares of Enron Mexico to Tractebel,
    S.A. (&quot;Tractebel&quot;) . Effective December 14, 2001, Enron Mexico changed it's
    name to Tractebel Energia de Monterrey, S. de R.L. de C.V. (&quot;Tractebel Energia
    de Monterrey&quot;) .</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">It is expected that
    Tractebel Energia de Monterrey will commence commercial operations during
    the third quarter of 2002.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    </i>The Company's consumption of gas during 2001 was 19,707,967 million British
    Thermal Units (&quot;MMBTUS&quot;) , of which, it had covered a total of 13,352,771
    MMBTUS with fixed price purchased contracts as follows:</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=648 align="center">
    <tr>
      <td width=327 valign=top class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=167 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b><u>%
          of coverage</u></b> <b><u>over consumption</u></b></font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=155 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b><u>MMBTUS
          </u></b> <b><u>coverage price</u></b></font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=327 valign=top class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Petroleos
        Mexicanos</font></td>
      <td width=167 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">30%</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=155 valign=top class="Normal">

          4.00</font></div>
      </td>

      </td>
      <td width=155 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">5.06</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=327 valign=top class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Enron</font></td>
      <td width=167 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">35%</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=155 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">3.68</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As
    a result of Enron's bankrupcy filing on December 2, 2001, the contracts between
    the Company and Enron terminated automatically.</font></p>
  <p class=MsoBodyText style='line-height:15.0pt;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As
    of December 31, 2001, the Company maintains hedges on price of natural gas
    for approximately 50% of its consumption with Petroleos Mexicanos at a price
    of $4.00 dollar per MMBTUS.</font></p>
  <p class=MsoBodyText style='line-height:15.0pt;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As
    of December 31, 2001, the market price for MMBTUS was $ 2.10 dollars.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c) </i> The Company
    has several non-cancellable operating lease agreements for the rent of warehouses
    and equipment. Rental expense for the years 1999, 2000 and 2001 was Ps. 239,
    Ps. 307 and Ps. 340, respectively.</font></p>
  <p class=MsoBodyText style='line-height:15.0pt;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Future
    minimum lease payments under these agreements are as follows:</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>d)
    </i>Sale of receivables - the Company has entered into several factoring agreements
    to sell trade accounts receivable. In accordance with the terms of these agreements,
    the Company has the obligation to pay uncollected receivables, in case of
    non-compliance of clients. The outstanding balance of receivables sold at
    December 31, 2001, amounted to $231. The Company periodically monitors collections
    to provide for any uncollectible account.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>e)
    </i>The Company is not a party, and none of its assets is subject, to any
    pending legal proceedings nor is the Company subject to any contingent liabilities,
    other than as described in note 4, and legal proceedings and contingent liabilities
    arising in the normal course of business and against which the Company is
    adequately insured or indemnified or which the Company believes are not material
    in the aggregate.</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>13.
    Stockholders' equity</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a)
    </i>At December 31, 2000 and 2001, the capital stock of the Company consisted
    of 324,000,000  ordinary, nominative, fully paid common shares, without par
    value.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    </i>The Company maintains an Employee Stock Option Plan established in March
    1998 (the &quot;Plan&quot;) . The Plan specifies amount of shares, time and initial
    exercise price, which is equal to the average closing price on the Mexican
    Stock Exchange of the common shares on the 20 days prior to the Grant Date,
    except for the options issued during 2000 and 2001, which were Ps. 11.00 and
    Ps. 8.27,  respectively. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    following table summarizes the activity relating to the Plan:</font></p>

          14.88</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Ps.
          11.00</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Ps.
          8.27</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=297 valign=top class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Exercise
        price at December 31, 2001</font></td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">33.45</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=120 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">15.92</font></div>

      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    closing price of the Company's shares on the Mexican Stock Exchange on December
    31, 2001 was Ps. 7.50.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    exercise price of the options granted in 1998 and 1999 will be determined
    at the time such options are exercised by indexing the initial price using
    an indexing factor based on the cumulative performance of the Company's common
    shares relative to the cumulative performance of the Indice de Precios y Cotizaciones
    of the Mexican Stock Exchange; such indexing factor is subject to certain
    ceilings and floors. There is no indexing factor for the options granted in
    2000 and 2001.</font></p>
  <p class=MsoBodyText style='line-height:15.0pt'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    estimated fair value of the options was made on the Grant Date using the Black-Scholes
    option-pricing model with the following assumptions:</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=300 align="center">
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=218 nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Risk-free
        interest rate</font></td>
      <td width=82 nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="left"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">15%</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Expected
        life in years</font></td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="left"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">5</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Price
        volatility</font></td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="left"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">44%</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class=MsoBodyText style='line-height:15.0pt'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">During
    2001, the Company repriced 940,950 of the options granted in 1998 to Ps. 13.00
    .  </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Compensation
    cost charged against income for such plan was Ps. 15,  Ps. 22  and Ps. 32
    for  1999, 2000 and 2001,  respectively. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c)
    </i>As of December 31, 2000 and 2001 the treasury shares held by the Company
    were 27,399,020 and 50,294,020, respectively, which include the shares held
    by Stock Option Trust (see note 13b) which were 1,779,020 and 24,674,020 as
    of December 31, 2000 and 2001, respectively.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>d)
    </i>Stockholders' equity, except restated paid-in capital and tax retained
    earnings will be subject to a 35% dividend tax, payable by the Company in
    the event of distribution. Beginning 2003 such tax rate will be reduced by
    1 percent each year through 2005. The tax paid for such dividend can be credited
    against the income tax of the Company during the three years following the
    payment. </font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>h)
    </i>At December 31, 2001, stockholders equity includes Ps. 290 of undistributed
    profits and Ps. 2,659 of other undistributed capital items of the subsidiaries.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>i)
    </i>Retained earnings reserved for reacquisition of Vitro's shares is the
    amount reserved pursuant to shareholders' meetings to repurchase shares of
    Vitro.  In accordance with Mexican regulations once the reserve is established,
    the Board of Directors has the authority to decide when such repurchase is
    made. </font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>j)
    </i>Comprehensive income (loss) that is reflected in the accompanying statements
    of Stockholders' Equity, represents the net result of the Company's performance
    each financial year, and consists of net income of each year plus other items
    of comprehensive income of the same period, which in accordance with the Mexican
    GAAP are reflected directly in Stockholders' Equity, without affecting the
    income statement. The other items of comprehensive income consist of the result
    of holding non-monetary assets and the minimum pension liability adjustment.
    In addition, in 2000 the comprehensive loss includes the cumulative effect
    of deferred income tax of Ps. 1,404 in majority interest and Ps. 1,064 in
    minority interest. Consequently, the comprehensive income (loss) of 2001 and
    1999,  are not comparable with  2000.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>14.
    Total financing cost</b></font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In
    1999 the Company downsized the production capacity of its Glass Containers
    business unit to match the market's demand.  The downsizing involved closing
    the facility known as Vidriera Oriental, located in Mexico City.  A charge
    of Ps. 764  was taken in 1999 to reduce the book value of the operation to
    its net realizable value associated with the plant shutdown.  Also in 1999,
    2000 and 2001 the Company downsized its corporate services at headquarters
    and certain business units, which resulted in a charge of Ps. 140 , Ps. 152
    and Ps. 319, respectively.</font></p>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>17.
    Income tax , workers' profit sharing and asset tax</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a)
    </i>The Company is subject to income tax and tax on assets for consolidation
    purposes in the proportion of the number of the subsidiary's voting shares
    that Vitro owns. Since January 1, 1999, the taxable income of the subsidiaries
    are consolidated at 60% of the mentioned proportion. The monthly tax advances
    to Secretaria de Hacienda y Credito Publico of Vitro as well as its subsidiaries,
    are made as if they have not elected tax consolidation.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    </i>The income tax and workers' profit sharing included in the Company's results
    are (the 2000 and 2001 amounts are not comparable with the 1999 amounts, see
    note 3 o) :</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=507 align="center">
    <tr>
      <td width=192 nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=315 nowrap colspan=3 valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Year
          ended December 31,</font></b></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">1999</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2000</font></b></div>
      </td>
      <td nowrap valign=bottom class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2001</font></b></div>
      </td>

  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c)
    </i>The income tax rate is 35%. In accordance with the new income tax law,
    which became effective on January 1, 2002,  the income tax rate will be reduced
    annually by 1% beginning 2003 through 2005. The effect of this decrease in
    the income tax rate will be recorded effective January 1, 2002 and will be
    a decrease in net long-term liabilities and an increase in net income of $172. Following
    is a reconciliation between the Company's effective income tax rate and the
    statutory rate (amounts of 2000 and 2001 are not comparable with those of
    1999, refer to note 3 o):</font></p>

        pension liability adjustment</font></td>

        <div align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">12</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">16</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=362 valign=top class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=102 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Ps.
          114</font></div>
      </td>
      <td width=105 valign=top class="Normal">
        <div align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Ps.
          179</font></div>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>18.
    Extraordinary item</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    extraordinary item in 1999 is the tax benefit that resulted from the utilization
    of tax loss carry forwards and the recovery of the asset tax paid in previous
    years.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b>19.
    Business acquisitions and dispositions</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>a) Sale of Silicatos y Derivados, S.A.- </i>In December 1999, Vitro sold its
    55% interest in Silicatos y Derivados, S.A., to its long-standing partner
    in such company, PQ Corporation, for $ 9.9 million.  A loss of Ps. 43 was
    realized as a result of this transaction and is included in Other expense,
    net.  This company produces sodium silicate and aluminum sulfate for the soap,
    detergent, water treatment and paper industries. The company's sales represented
    approximately 1.4% of Vitro's consolidated sales.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>b)
    Sale of Compania Manufacturera de Vidrio del Peru Ltda, S.A.</i>- In December
    1999, Vitro accepted the November 17, 1999 public tender offer made by Vidrios
    Industriales, S.A. (a subsidiary of Owens-Illinois, Inc.) for its 23.66% interest
    of Compania Manufacturera de Vidrio de Peru Ltda, S.A. The amount received
    for the sale was $ 6.6 million. A loss of Ps. 40 was realized as a result
    of this transaction and is included in Other expense, net. Vitro accounted
    for this investment, under the equity method.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>c) Acquisition of Harding Glass Inc</i>.- In April 2000, VVP America consummated
    the acquisition of substantially all of the assets of Harding Glass, Inc.,
    for an amount of $ 31.4 million.  With the acquisition of Harding, VVP America
    incorporated into its operations 5 distribution centers and 118 retail stores
    located throughout the United States. Harding is one of the leading distributors
    of glass products for automotive and construction markets.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>d) Disposition of Manufacturas, Ensamblajes y Fundiciones, S. de R. L. de C.V.-</i>
    On August 10, 2000 Vitro and GE Mexico, S.A. de C.V. a subsidiary of General
    Electric Company, a U.S. Corporation, decided to terminate their Joint Venture
    Agreement which in 1997 resulted in the creation of Manufacturas, Ensamblajes
    y Fundiciones, S. de R.L. de C.V.  The termination of the joint venture was
    subject to compliance with certain requirements imposed by both parties. Those
    requirements were completed in January 2001, resulting in the closing of such
    facility.  A loss of Ps. 72 was recognized and is included in Other expense,
    net.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>e) Sale of
    Regioplast, S.A. de C.V.-</i> On May 21, 2001, Vitro sold its 50% interest
    in Regioplast, S.A. de C.V. to Owens Illinois Inc., former partner of Vitro
    in such company, for an amount of $ 8.0 million. A loss of Ps. 81 was realized
    as a result of this transaction and is included in Other expense, net.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><i>f) Acquisition
    of Cristalglass Vidrio Aislante, S.A. - </i>On May 4, 2001 the Company acquired
    60 percent of the outstanding shares of Spain's Cristalglass Vidrio Aislante,
    S.A., holding company of Group Cristalglass.  Cristalglass fabricates, distributes
    and sells flat glass for the construction industry. The company employs over
    300 people. Annual sales are approximately  $ 60 million.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><br>20. Business
    segment data</b></font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The
    accounting policies of the segments are the same as those described in notes
    2 and 3.  The Company evaluates the performance of its segments on the basis
    of operating income.  Intersegment sales and transfers are accounted for as
    if the sales and transfers were to third parties, that is, at current market
    prices.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Vitro's
    reportable segments are strategic business units that offer different products.
    The segments are managed separately; each requires different manufacturing
    operations, technology and marketing strategies; and each segment primarily
    serves a different customer base.</font></p>
  <p style='text-align:justify;'><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Beginning
    October 1, 2001, the Company has four reportable segments: Glass Containers,
    Flat Glass, Acros-Whirlpool and Glassware. The companies previously part of
    the former Diverse Industries Business Unit were reallocated to the four existing
    reportable segments to vertically integrate operations and to better realign
    ourselves with our market needs.  For comparison purposes, the amounts of
    previous years have been reclassified to present the information in four reportable
    segments. The principal products of each of the segments are summarized below:</font></p>
  <table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=567 align="center">
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=138 valign=bottom class="Normal"> <b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Segment</font></b></td>
      <td width=429 valign=bottom class="Normal"> <b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Principal
        products</font></b></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=138 valign=bottom class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
      <td width=429 valign=bottom class="Normal">&nbsp; </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width=138 valign=middle class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Glass
        Containers</font></td>
      <td width=429 valign=bottom class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Glass
        containers, sodium carbonate, borosilicate glass, capital   goods, aluminum
        cans, precision components and molds for glass industry.</font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCFFFF">
      <td width=138 valign=middle class="Normal"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Flat

    </tr>
